Speaker.P: In my address to the confederation, I indicated the difficulties facing us which, while serious, do not provide evidence of “accelerating economic decline”; and I indicated the Government's intention of taking whatever action was necessary to keep the economy on course. Decisions to this end will be announced as appropriate.
I may also mention that the working party, arising out of the meetings between members of the Government and economic organisations, will be meeting very soon.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Lynch Mr. J. Lynch
Speaker.P: Will the Taoiseach agree that the indications of the decline in the economy were very apparent as far back as November last year? Why were appropriate measures not taken as of that date?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Liam Cosgrave
Speaker.P: No, I do not agree. In fact, the budget was designed to stimulate the economy because of the recession both outside and inside the country. I should say that the volume of industrial investment shows an increase in each of the past years and I can quote figures to indicate this. There was £135 million worth of work approved by the IDA in 1972-73, £303 million worth in 1973-74, and £510 million worth in 1974. For the same period the value of exports was up 29 per cent.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Lynch Mr. J. Lynch
Speaker.P: Would the Taoiseach not agree that the increase in the volume of money generated by the IDA was as a result of measures taken before this Government took office when the economy was on a sound basis? Will he further indicate why he denies that the decline in the economy is accelerating when all the evidence is pointing to that fact?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Liam Cosgrave
Speaker.P: In fact, the value of exports which I mentioned was £254 million or 29 per cent in 1974 and industrial exports were up more than 40 per cent despite the depressed conditions in other markets.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Lynch Mr. J. Lynch
Speaker.P: Will the Taoiseach indicate why it was necessary to invite representatives of different organisations such as farmers, employers, trade unions and others to meetings when there was already in existence the National Economic and Social Council on which all these bodies were already represented? Will he say what expertise the new committees or groups have that the NESC does not have?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Liam Cosgrave
Speaker.P: I am sure the Deputy appreciates that the NESC is a very large body and large bodies generally take time to come to conclusions. It was felt that because of the continuing rate of inflation it was necessary to take action more quickly. It was for that reason that an invitation was extended to the bodies concerned and the suggestion made that smaller representation from the different interests might result in more speedy action.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Lynch Mr. J. Lynch
Speaker.P: Will the Taoiseach not agree that there is already within the NESC a number of committees and more specifically an economic committee? If it were a question of the NESC as a whole being too unwieldy, would not the economic committee of the NESC have been adequate for the purpose which the Taoiseach has in mind?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Liam Cosgrave
Speaker.P: As the Deputy says, there is the economic committee but I think it is correct to say that most of the representatives on the working party are also members of the NESC.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Lynch Mr. J. Lynch
Speaker.P: If they are all members of the NESC, why was it necessary to set up a new body? Was it not just a charade to try to indicate that the Government were doing something at last having been goaded and pilloried into taking some action?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Liam Cosgrave
Speaker.P: In fact, the suggestion of a smaller working group came originally from one of the ICTU representatives as being the most effective way. The Government are anxious to co-operate in any ideas which these organisations put forward as constructive approaches to deal with the situation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Lynch Mr. J. Lynch
Speaker.P: In view of the necessity which the Government saw for setting up this new group and these working committees, is it now admitted that the concept of a national partnership which was put forward by the Government in a White Paper last year has failed or is no longer effective? In view of the statement recently by the Minister for Labour urging restraint in wage claims, does that in any way prejudice adherence to the national wage agreement on the part of the Government?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Liam Cosgrave
Speaker.P: No. So far as the national partnership is concerned, this is a follow-up to the suggestion contained in the White Paper when it was published but, in the meantime, as the Deputy knows, discussions had been proceeding on the national wage agreement and it was felt that intervention by the Government would possibly be regarded as interferences with those discussions. Now that the discussions on wages have ended it was decided to reconvene the meetings between the different organisations. So far as the statement by the Minister for Labour was concerned, I think he correctly represented the situation. One of the problems involved in inflation is the high level of the percentage changes involved in the implementation of the national wage agreement.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Lynch Mr. J. Lynch
Speaker.P: Is it the position now that the Government have no plans or proposals to keep the economy on course, to use the Taoiseach's own phrase, and that we must await the outcome of the discussions by the committees who are now coming together, and who may be engaged in protracted meetings, before any necessary measures will be taken?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Liam Cosgrave
Speaker.P: No, on the contrary. I made it clear that the Government were anxious to proceed on the basis of consultation with the interested parties to which I have referred. I also made it clear that so far as action is concerned in the budget in January and on whatever other occasions seem appropriate the Government will take the necessary action.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Lynch Mr. J. Lynch
Speaker.P: Since one of these measures was the imposition of an enormous tax increase on petrol, would the Taoiseach indicate what consultations took place with the interested bodies?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Liam Cosgrave
Speaker.P: Apparently when you take action you are criticised. On that occasion we took action.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Lynch Mr. J. Lynch
Speaker.P: The Taoiseach cannot have it both ways.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Malley Mr. O'Malley
Speaker.P: How does the Taoiseach reconcile his statement today with his recent statement that we are living largely on borrowed time and on the goodwill of our creditors?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: I have allowed many supplementaries on this question. Question No. 2.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Employment Statistics.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Malley Mr. O'Malley
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach the number of unemployed registered in Limerick city at the latest available date and the percentage of the insured population of the city which this represents.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) (for the Taoiseach) Richard Burke
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education (Mr. R. Burke) (for the Taoiseach)
Speaker.P: The number of persons residing in Limerick city on the live register at the end of April, 1975, was 3,444. Figures for the insured population resident in Limerick city are not available.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Malley Mr. O'Malley
Speaker.P: Would I be correct in saying that on those figures alone the percentage of the insured population of Limerick city registered as unemployed at the moment is in excess of 10 per cent?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: As I told the Deputy, the figures for the insured population are not available.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Coughlan Mr. Coughlan
Speaker.P: Would the Minister not emphasise the fact that we had a much larger unemployment figure in Limerick city and we gave them free beef?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: This is a statistical question. I cannot allow matters of policy to be adverted to.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Coughlan Mr. Coughlan
Speaker.P: They are now getting substantial social welfare payments.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Lynch Mr. J. Lynch
Speaker.P: There was a famine in 1849.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Coughlan Mr. Coughlan
Speaker.P: There is another famine in Fianna Fáil in 1975.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Lynch Mr. J. Lynch
Speaker.P: There is a famine of economic ideas on the other side of the House.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Coughlan Mr. Coughlan
Speaker.P: Fianna Fáil are brainless and thoughtless.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Malley Mr. O'Malley
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach the unemployment figures of each of the nine EEC countries as a percentage of the work force at the latest available date.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: The systems under which short-term unemployment statistics are compiled and the definitions and concepts involved, vary considerably from country to country, and it is not possible to quote comparable unemployment totals, or unemployment rates, for the different EEC countries.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Malley Mr. O'Malley
Speaker.P: Is the fact that the Minister on behalf of the Taoiseach who is present refuses to answer either this question or the previous question due to the fact that these figures which are well known are very embarrassing to the Government?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: On the contrary. The indications which are coming from another source and which will be published today show, in effect, that if one takes the period 1974-75 Ireland is faring better than most countries in Europe and in some countries the increase in unemployment is 337 per cent, 294 per cent, 55 per cent and 69 per cent, so we are not doing badly at all by comparison with other European countries.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Education Facilities.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Loughnane Dr. Loughnane
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the up-to-date position regarding his Department's plans for education at post-primary schools in (a) Tulla (b) Killaloe and (c) Scariff, County Clare.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: Sanction in principle has been given by my Department for the erection of permanent buildings at Scariff Vocational School to replace profabricated buildings. It has also been agreed to examine the accommodation situation in the Tulla school having regard to the area's potential school enrolment, etc., and this matter is at present under consideration. No particular action appears to be required at present in relation to educational facilities in Killaloe.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Loughnane Dr. Loughnane
Speaker.P: That is satisfactory.

Speaker.hpid: Ruarí Brugha Ruarí Brugha
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he will outline his immediate and long-term proposals for the provision of adequate post-primary education facilities in South County Dublin.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: It is proposed to cater for the immediate post-primary needs of this area by the provision of schools in Ballyroan, Lucan, Cabinteely, Old Bawn and Springfield districts.

MainHeading.P: In the longer term schools will be provided in the Balally-Sandyford and the Holylands and Rathfarnham areas, as well as at least seven additional schools in the Tallaght area. Building in each case will be timed to coincide with the accommodation requirements for the increased potential enrolments.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Emigrant Teacher Deputation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education when he intends to meet a deputation of the returned emigrant teachers' action group.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: I would refer the Deputy to my reply of 21 January, 1975, to a question from him concerning the recognition of teaching service abroad. The aspects of the matter to which I adverted in that reply are still sub judice, and in the circumstances it would be inappropriate for me to receive a deputation from the group in question before the judgment of the Supreme Court becomes available.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: Is the Minister aware that at the time I pointed out to him that the question sub judice was one of discrimination as between a lay teacher and a teacher in Holy Orders and has nothing to do with this issue at all, and that the group concerned has since then taken senior counsel's advice and that his advice is that this is the case.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: I am aware that the Deputy made that point, but I pointed out to him in reply that to have conceded credit to lay teachers would have placed me as Minister in contempt of court and to have conceded it for lay and religious teachers would have rendered my appeal to the Supreme Court ludicrous.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: The Minister knows he is talking nonsense. Is this a manner which the Minister has for delaying recognition of service overseas to teachers whom he specifically invited back to this country, saying in a letter I have here that if he got power, he would immediately give incremental allowances to teachers overseas?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: The Deputy is aware that I did not take the action which led to the Supreme Court action in question, and until the judgment is delivered in this case, I cannot take any effective action.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: Does the Minister recognise the style of this statement? “May I assure you that as a former practising teacher, I am very much in favour of the extension of incremental recognition for worthwhile experience gained overseas”, sent to some person in Canada——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Quotations are not in order at Question Time.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: ——and that this person came back thinking that the Minister was a man of his word. I am simply probing—I believe he still may be—to see is the Minister using this court case he need not use to postpone a decision on this matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: I have replied to the Deputy on the two points, that to have done one thing would have made me act as if I were in contempt of court, and to have done the other would have made my appeal in the case ludicrous, and I think that is sufficient answer.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: Does the Minister agree with the wording of that letter, that all he needed was power to make these teachers——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: The Deputy has already made that point.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: The Deputy is making a different point, with respect.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: I have given Deputies some latitude on this subject.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: I am asking the Minister was he advised by his legal advisers that he could not grant recognition for service abroad to any teacher because of this court action. I am asking that straight and blunt.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: I have already answered the Deputy's question on that point twice. I cannot add anything to the answer already given.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Wilson Mr. Wilson
Speaker.P: Specifically I am asking now has the Minister legal advice that he cannot grant recognition for service abroad to any teacher because of this court case?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: The Minister is aware of the relevance of the sub judice rules in these matters.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Malley Mr. O'Malley
Speaker.P: Withdraw your appeal and it will not be relevant.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - School Transport Service.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Walsh Mr. Walsh
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education why school transport has been withdrawn from a pupil (name supplied) who is attending Celbridge School, County Kildare.

Speaker.hpid: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education (Mr. Bruton) John Bruton
Speaker.NameTxt: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education (Mr. Bruton)
Speaker.P: My information is that transport was not withdrawn from the child in question. I understand that the parents moved house and that transport has now been provided from their new house.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Walsh Mr. Walsh
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education why school transport has not been provided for children from the Saggart area, County Dublin, attending Tallaght community school.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bruton Mr. Bruton
Speaker.P: There are adequate post-primary schools in Clondalkin, the nearest post-primary centre to the Saggart area and, in accordance with the terms of the free transport scheme, transport on CIE public services is provided to Clondalkin for eligible Saggart pupils.

Such pupils who wish to attend Tallaght community school are allowed the concession of free school transport on the public services from the Embankment, which is the pickup point nearest to the Tallaght catchment boundary. This is the most which can be allowed under the terms of the free transport scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Walsh Mr. Walsh
Speaker.P: Is the Parliamentary Secretary aware that to walk from Saggart village to the Embankment involves a couple of miles? Surely he does not expect children to walk that distance in bad weather. I appeal to him to reconsider his decision in the matter and allow this free transport.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bruton Mr. Bruton
Speaker.P: I understand that the children in the Saggart area already have adequate transport arrangements to schools in their nearest centre which is Clondalkin, and under the regulations all that can be allowed to them in going to a centre other than their nearest centre is a catchment boundary service.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Walsh Mr. Walsh
Speaker.P: Is the Parliamentary Secretary aware that on a number of occasions these people are not able to get to school on account of bad weather? I again appeal to him to reconsider his decision.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bruton Mr. Bruton
Speaker.P: I can assure the Deputy that children in this area are getting services which children are getting everywhere in the country.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - School Children's Bus Fares.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Blaney Mr. Blaney
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he will take the necessary action to ensure that bus fares for school children will not be increased by up to 50 per cent as has been proposed.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bruton Mr. Bruton
Speaker.P: The fares increases authorised by the Government in respect of CIE public services apply to all categories of travellers, including school children. Less than 4 per cent of fare-paying school children will be required to pay more than an extra 1p per journey.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Blaney Mr. Blaney
Speaker.P: The Parliamentary Secretary has not adverted to the fact that the 1p increase for school children in many cases, and particularly in this city, does represent a 50 per cent increase. Whereas we were appalled by the 33? per cent increase, it is 50 per cent as far as school children are concerned.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bruton Mr. Bruton
Speaker.P: In the case of the minimum fare, that was the case, an increase from 2p to 3p, but in no other case is the increase 50 per cent.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Blaney Mr. Blaney
Speaker.P: The Parliamentary Secretary is in no way sympathetic to the situation in which school children are faced with paying 50 per cent more this week than before.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bruton Mr. Bruton
Speaker.P: The simple fact is that to ensure that no increase took place in school children's fares would have involved an extra subvention of £463,000.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Blaney Mr. Blaney
Speaker.P: Surely with all the millions that are scattered around, the extra £400,000 talked about is no more than pin money and should not be held against these people.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bruton Mr. Bruton
Speaker.P: I do not accept the contention of the Deputy.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Intoxicating Liquor Laws.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Enright Mr. Enright
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he proposes to initiate legislation to amend the Intoxicating Liquor Acts.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Enright Mr. Enright
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if there are any proposals before his Department to amend the Intoxicating Liquor Acts in so far as they relate to the hours of opening and closing of licensed premises on weekdays and Sundays.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Lands (Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick, Cavan) (for the Minister for Justice) Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: , Cavan) (for the Minister for Justice): With the permission of the Ceann Comhairle, I propose to take Questions Nos. 10 and 11 together.

Various proposals have been made to me from time to time in relation to possible amendments of the Intoxicating Liquor Acts. These proposals include some relating to the hours of opening of licensed premises. I am examining the proposals but no decision has been taken to introduce amending legislation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Enright Mr. Enright
Speaker.P: Is the Minister in a position to confirm that a large section of the Vintners' Federation of Ireland are anxious that the hours of opening of licensed premises should be until 11 p.m. seven nights of the week all year round?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): Various proposals have been put before the Minister and the suggestion mentioned by the Deputy was also put forward.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Enright Mr. Enright
Speaker.P: Would the Minister not consider that during the tourist season 11 o'clock closing on a Sunday night is desirable?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): The entire matter is being considered and it would not be advisable to deal with it piecemeal.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Loughnane Dr. Loughnane
Speaker.P: Is the Department having uniformity in closing hours for the types of licences that exist? There is a normal licence and a restricted licence. Under the latter there is early closing and restriction to six days. In some villages where early closing operates people are breaking the law if they stay five minutes over a specific time but they can go to the licensed premises next door where they are not breaking the law. In remote places some premises only have a six-day licence. Could a seven-day licence be granted to the holders of six-day licences on the payment of a satisfactory fee?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): The number of licences mentioned by the Deputy are few and far between. The Minister has received proposals to give six-day licence holders an opportunity of converting their licences into seven-day licences. Perhaps the point the Deputy is now making could be relevantly made when a Bill comes before the House.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Loughnane Dr. Loughnane
Speaker.P: In restricted licences there is also what they call a seven-day early closing. It is a very old one but there are some.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): They are few and far between.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Toal Mr. Toal
Speaker.P: Would the Minister agree that the indiscriminate granting of extensions to hotels to run discotheques and public dances gives rise to serious teenage drinking and that this area in the licensing laws should be changed.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): That is a separate question and I believe it deals more with the enforcement of the existing law.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Next question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: Are such things barred under the existing law?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: I have called the next question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: The Chair should allow a supplementary question especially when progress is being made.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: The Deputy should allow the Chair to control Question Time.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Use of Breathalyser.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lemass Mr. Lemass
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he has considered permitting the use of the breathalyser in relation to students of 17 years of age.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): I regret that I do not understand the point of the question.

The use of breathalyser equipment is regulated by law and not by me. The legislation does not provide for any exemption from the breathalyser based on age or status and the question of my permitting it does not arise.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lemass Mr. Lemass
Speaker.P: Has the Minister seen reports of where children of between 13 and 14 years of age arrived at school under the influence of alcohol? Has the Minister any proposals to prevent this taking place?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): The Deputy asks in his question if the Minister has considered permitting the use of the breathalyser in relation to students of 17 years of age but, as the Deputy appreciates, the breathalyser was brought into operation to deal with Road Traffic Acts and not with a situation where people are drinking under age, as the Deputy refers to.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lemass Mr. Lemass
Speaker.P: Does the Minister appreciate that a child who may have a stomach upset or who could not sleep because of a bad headache may be suspected by his teacher of having taken alcohol? If so, would he not consider that rather than having the teacher taking arbitrary action it would be better to establish whether he has taken alcohol or not? In the event of the child having taken alcohol, does the Minister not consider it is time to take remedial action?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): I hope the situation has not arisen where the breathalyser should be recommended for use on children arriving at school.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Border Infringements.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Dowling Mr. Dowling
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if his attention has been drawn to a report (details supplied) to the effect that the three soldiers arrested in Clones, County Monaghan, were later escorted back to the North on Government instructions; whether this report is correct; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): I am aware of the incident referred to in the question. When the Garda Síochána had satisfied themselves that the incursion was the result of a mistake by the soldiers, who were new to the area, gardaí escorted them back across the Border.
I am informed by my colleague, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, that the British Government have conveyed apologies to the Irish Government for this incursion.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: Do we take it that it is accepted policy that any such people will be just led across the Border again?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): That would be wrong. The Deputy may take it that every case will be treated on its merits and on the circumstances surrounding it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: Did the Minister receive apologies from the British authorities for all the incursions which occurred but were not detected?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: That is a separate matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): I have dealt with the incident referred to in the question and the British Government conveyed an apology to the Irish Government for that incursion.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Loughnane Dr. Loughnane
Speaker.P: Did British forces cross the Border into Clones on previous occasions?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: We cannot deal with previous occasions.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: The Minister might as well not be answering these questions.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: I will only deal with the questions on the Order Paper.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. MacSharry Mr. MacSharry
Speaker.P: The Chair might as well run through them all at once if that is the position. The situation is ridiculous.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - County Limerick Garda Station.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the present position regarding the provision of a new garda barracks at Kilmallock, County Limerick.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): The Commissioner of the Garda Síochána is reviewing the distribution of gardaí in the Limerick Division. This will involve a decision on the number of gardaí for whom accommodation will be required in Kilmallock and, accordingly, the plans for the new station there, for which a site has been acquired, cannot be prepared until the review is completed which may not be for some months yet.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Garda Educational Facilities.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he intends granting day release facilities to members of the gardaí who are pursuing courses in law in third-level educational institutions in Ireland.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): The arrangements which apply in the Garda Síochána for the release of members of the force at public expense for higher-level education are identical with those applicable to other branches of the public service. The object of the arrangements is to meet particular needs in the force by providing training for specific posts requiring specialised knowledge, that is, training which cannot economically or adequately be provided as part of normal in-service training. Various other specialist courses are, of course, already provided for the Garda Síochána.

The needs of the force in regard to specialised courses are primarily a matter for assessment by the Commissioner. I am informed by him that, at present, these needs are being met, as far as specialised full-time university courses are concerned, by sending three members on such courses. One of these members is studying for a law degree. The members concerned were selected following the issue of circulars to the force inviting applications for these training opportunities. The matter will be reviewed in the light of experience.

I think it right, however, to draw attention to the fact that any question of affording special facilities to any particular members to pursue courses of their own choice raises serious questions of equity as between these members and other members whose duty arrangements may be affected as a result, and who, in addition, may later find themselves at a disadvantage.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Cashel Garda Station.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if it is proposed that Cashel Garda Station, County Tipperary, will be reopened until 12 p.m. each night.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): I would refer the Deputy to the reply I gave on 15th November, 1974, to a similar question put down by him. The position continues to be as explained in that reply.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: Now that this is a radio base and that it is the only town in South Tipperary that does not have a Garda station operating through the night, does the Minister not consider that the least that should be done is to open it until midnight? This is the only town between Abbeyleix and Cahir, 40 miles of the main Dublin-Cork road, with no Garda station.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): I understand that when the station is closed people in need of gardaí can telephone Cahir, which is ten miles away, and that there is a telephone kiosk outside. I understand also that the town is patrolled between 9 p.m. and 12 midnight and frequently between 9 p.m. and 4 a.m., that the patrols call at Cashel Barracks and telephone Cahir to ascertain whether or not they have received any request for assistance or police help. I am informed also that there is a patrol car attached to Cashel station which performs patrols until 4 a.m. each morning.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: Is the Minister aware that, in certain circumstances locally, people may want to speak to a local garda whom they know, in the event of any trouble, rather than to a stranger ten or 15 miles away, a garda whom they do not know, when a local garda might be able to handle the local problem without any action being taken legally.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): I do not want to become argumentative with the Deputy, but I think if anybody wants a garda during the hours when the stations are closed it would probably be an emergency matter and that any garda would be welcomed.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: Further arising——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: We must get on to other Questions.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: In the event of, say, a wife being beaten—I know of such a case recently—she would not go to a Garda station outside the area but she would consult one of the local gardaí if they were readily available to her.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): I do not think the Deputy is being realistic because, if the Garda station was open, the unfortunate woman would have no assurance that a garda whom she knew would be on duty.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: But at least she could talk to him.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Garda Uniforms.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lemass Mr. Lemass
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice when the gardaí will be supplied with suitable summer uniforms.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): It is expected that all members will be supplied with summer uniforms within the next two months.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lemass Mr. Lemass
Speaker.P: Could the Minister explain the reason for the delay in this matter; whether it is suggested that they should be available now?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): I could. Following recommendations, an order was placed in July, 1972 with the Controller of Stores, Department of Posts and Telegraphs, for a sample of material to an agreed specification. That sample did not arrive until March, 1973 and a limited number of new style shirts were made from that sample and supplied to the force in June, 1973. Bulk supplies of the new material were ordered in August, 1973 and became available only in July, 1974, Adequate supplies of all materials are now available, and all the required——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lemass Mr. Lemass
Speaker.P: Is it not very peculiar that, with all we read about recession in the textile trade, it takes nine months from the time of the ordering of the sample, years and years apparently, when Irish factories are crying out for work and contracts; that the Department of Posts and Telegraphs who carry responsibility as well as the Department of Justice could not place these contracts?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): The Department of Posts and Telegraphs act merely as ordering agents. The trouble has been continuing here since April, 1972.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Question No. 18.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lemass Mr. Lemass
Speaker.P: With your permission, Sir, I should like to postpone Questions Nos. 18, 30, 31, 32 and 33 until the Minister is here to deal with them. Some of the latter ones are very important. I know the Minister answering now is not responsible for that Department.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: It is usual to give the Chair earlier notice of this, Deputy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lemass Mr. Lemass
Speaker.P: It arose only out of the unsatisfactory answers I have been receiving to questions up to now.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: It leaves the Chair and the Minister in a very difficult position.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): I bow to your ruling, a Cheann Comhairle, but I am quite prepared to answer all the questions on the Order Paper directed to the Minister for Justice.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lemass Mr. Lemass
Speaker.P: Might I draw the Chair's attention to a precedent—on the very first occasion when I was answering questions, on the Government side of the House, I found myself with the brief of the Minister for Finance at an hour's notice. I found it very difficult to answer some questions, except to give a reply such as —“I will bring the Deputy's remarks to the attention of the Minister.” Both Deputy Tom O'Higgins and Deputy Oliver J. Flanagan withdrew their questions, with the consent of the Chair.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): I can assure the Deputy that I did not receive this brief at an hour's notice. I went into these questions with the Minister for Justice last night.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Would the Deputy please repeat the numbers of the Questions involved?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lemass Mr. Lemass
Speaker.P: 18, 30, 31, 32 and 33. The Vietnam questions are the most important ones. If the Minister would prefer to proceed with Question No. 18, that is all right.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Does the Deputy want Question No. 18 replied to now?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lemass Mr. Lemass
Speaker.P: I realise it is late notice but, if the Chair would agree to the postponement of Questions Nos. 32 and 33—about which I am most concerned—I will let the others go ahead.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Ban-Ghardaí Pay and Promotion

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lemass Mr. Lemass
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if, in view of the fact that this year is International Women's Year, he will ensure that equal opportunities for pay and for promotion above the rank of sergeant will be granted to Ban-Ghardaí; and whether they will in future be permitted to join the detective branch.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): Discussions with the Garda Representative Bodies on claims for the application to the Garda Síochána of the principle of equal pay for men and women doing the same or similar work or work of equal value are in progress under the Garda Síochána conciliation and arbitration scheme.

Having regard to the nature of many of the duties that gardaí are called on to perform, the question of affording to women within the Force equality of opportunity in regard to the assignment of duties and the related matter of promotion is a complex one, which is being examined in consultation with the Commissioner.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lemass Mr. Lemass
Speaker.P: Could the Minister give an assurance that in this International Women's Year we will get a decision on this matter before the year expires?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): I will convey that request to the Minister.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Monaghan and Dublin Bombings.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the progress that has been made in the investigations of the Monaghan and Dublin bombings in May, 1974.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): I am informed by the Commissioner of the Garda Síochána that Garda investigations of these outrages continue although nobody has so far been made amenable for them.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: Is the Minister not aware that it is a well-known fact that three people have been arrested, interned in Northern Ireland and released who, it is well known, were responsible for this outrage?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): I have no more information of a specific nature about that than has the Deputy. As far as the Garda Síochána are concerned, they have not received evidence from the RUC that particular persons perpetrated these outrages. They have no positive information or evidence that would identify the culprits.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: Is it not a fact that the Under Secretary of State for Northern Ireland stated that those three people were in their custody at one stage?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): I understand that is so. But, in so far as the Garda Síochána are concerned, they have no positive information with which to identify the people who committed these outrages.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: In other words, the Minister is saying co-operation is on one side only. Surely the information as to the people responsible for these terrible outrages just over a year ago this month would have been passed on to the Garda Síochána?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): I am not saying that. The fact that these people were interned might suggest—if they were interned—there was not evidence sufficient to sustain conviction. Even if these were the people who were guilty, the offence was committed here and, unless the reciprocal legislation which is now being sponsored here and in Britain were available, it would not be possible to bring these people to justice in Northern Ireland for crimes committed here.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: The Minister gave an indication that he did not even know who committed those crimes?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): Neither do I.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: Is the Minister not aware of the fact that the Under Secretary of State was certain who were the people involved?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: The Deputy has already posed that supplementary question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): I have only the same information as the Deputy.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Unmarried Mothers' Legislation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Hotel Licences.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gallagher Mr. Gallagher
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he is aware that a number of hoteliers and guest-house owners who obtained hotel licences under an Act passed in 1902 are now threatened with losing their licences due to standards being demanded by Bord Fáilte (details supplied); and if he will take steps to protect the interests of these people.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): I think I should explain, for the record, that the detail supplied by the Deputy in relation to this question was a reference to section 20 of the Intoxicating Liquor Act, 1960.

MainHeading.P: That section provides that where, after the passing of the Act, a licence is obtained (i.e. obtained for the first time) in respect of a premises on the basis that it is a hotel within the meaning of the Licensing Acts, the licence may not be renewed (at the annual licensing session) unless it is shown to the satisfaction of the Court that the premises is registered in the register of hotels kept by Bord Fáilte.

Since I have no function in regard to the standards prescribed by Bord Fáilte, I assume that what the Deputy wishes me to do is to introduce legislation to amend or repeal the section of the 1960 Act to which he has referred. I indicated to-day in reply to a parliamentary question that various proposals for the amendment of the Acts have been made, that I am examining them but that no decision has yet been taken to introduce amending legislation. The most I can say at this stage in relation to section 20 of the 1960 Act is that it was introduced following a recommendation of an Intoxicating Liquor Commission and that it has obviously much to commend it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gallagher Mr. Gallagher
Speaker.P: Is the Minister aware that a number of people got licences under the 1902 Act; that at that time there was no statutory provision as to what was a hotel and that subsequent Acts have changed the situation, meaning that people who have been doing business over a long number of years find now they are no longer entitled to a licence? In view of this would the Minister reconsider the whole position in relation to this matter?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): With great respect, I think the Deputy is incorrect. People who got licences, as hotel licences, under the 1902 Act are in no way affected by the register of hotels kept by Bord Fáilte; they continue to hold their licences. This provision applies only to people who got licences, as hotel licences, after the passage of the 1960 Act. Those people who got licences under the 1960 Act got them in respect of premises that were hotels and were registered by Bord Fáilte. It is only if the hotels have been downgraded by Bord Fáilte and removed from the register of hotels that they lose the licence.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gallagher Mr. Gallagher
Speaker.P: I am afraid that is not the information I have received. Is the Minister aware that a number of hotel owners and guest-house owners who had licences prior to the 1960 Act have been told in the courts that they are no longer entitled to call themselves hoteliers because the 1960 Act does not give them a grading?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): They may not be entitled to call themselves hoteliers but if they had their publican's licence before 1960 they can still retain it. That is my understanding.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gallagher Mr. Gallagher
Speaker.P: Information which I have been given by a member of the legal profession——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): They are not all infallible.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gallagher Mr. Gallagher
Speaker.P: I am told that five hoteliers in Mayo have been told by the courts that they are not entitled to sell intoxicating liquor.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): I am telling the Deputy those five people must have obtained their publican's licence for the first time subsequent to the passing of the Intoxicating Liquor Act, 1960. If that is not so and when the matter is looked into the Deputy will receive a communication from the Department of Justice and the matter will be put right. I am convinced what I have said is correct.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Legislative Proposals.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Collins Mr. G. Collins
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the legislation he intends to initiate within 12 months from the 1st May, 1975; and the approximate date in the case of each Bill.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): In replying on 16th May, 1974, to a similar question, I pointed out that the introduction of legislation by a Minister requires the specific approval of the Government and has to compete for its place in the parliamentary timetable, and that when the Government have approved in principle of new legislation, even an apparently simple Bill frequently gives rise to complex legal difficulties so that any attempt to set specific or even approximate dates for the introduction of a series of Bills during the coming 12 months would be wholly unrealistic.
I am not, accordingly, prepared to say more than that I hope to introduce several Bills during the coming year on a variety of subjects, which will include one or more Bills on aspects of family law.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Treatment in Prisons.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Gibbons Dr. Gibbons
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the number of prisoners that have been punished by solitary confinement or by dietary restriction during the past year; and if he will make a statement on the content of dietary restriction and the manner in which it is operated.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): During the past year, 12 prisoners incurred dietary restriction with close confinement—ten for three days, one for two days and one for one day. In six of these instances the punishment was imposed for assaults involving violence to prison officers or to other prisoners. In another three instances the punishment was imposed for a concerted attempt to wreck a section of the prison. In the remaining three instances the punishment was imposed for open defiance of the prison staff.

During the year two prisoners were punished with close confinement without dietary punishment. In each case the confinement was for three days. One of these was punished for assualt and one for persisting with disorderly conduct.
The restricted diet is prescribed in regulations under the statutory rules and consists of a total of 12 ounces of bread, eight ounces of potatoes and water per day.

In order to complete the picture and because some people appear to have erroneous impressions about segregation in Mountjoy Prison, I think I might mention that, while it is often necessary to keep a small number of prisoners segregated in the case of a wing there, the accommodation in the base is comparable to accommodation anywhere else in the prison and the windows are above ground level, with full access to daylight. The number in the base varies from time to time but it is usually between 12 and 15. At the present time five prisoners are in the base because they have good reasons for wanting to be segregated from the rest of the prisoners. A further nine are segregated there in the interests of safe custody and good order. Ordinarily the prisoners segregated there work and associate to the same extent as they would if they were elsewhere in the prison. There are, however, two prisoners who are particularly difficult to control and it is regrettably necessary to have them confined to their cells save when they are on outdoor exercise.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Moneylenders Act.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. O'Connell Dr. O'Connell
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice when it is proposed to initiate legislation to amend the Moneylenders Act, 1933.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. O'Connell Dr. O'Connell
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the response, if any, he has received to his invitation to community associations to make submissions for amending the Moneylenders Act, 1933.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)
Speaker.P: (Cavan): With the permission of the Ceann Comhairle, I propose to take Questions Nos. 37 and 38 together.

In reply to a parliamentary question by the Deputy on 16th May, 1974, I indicated that it would be necessary to make a minor amendment of the Moneylenders Act, 1933—relating to a citizenship provision—to comply with our EEC obligations and, in that context, any other amendment that seemed desirable could be introduced. I asked that any interested organisation should send in their views, preferably in writing, within six weeks or so.

Since I answered that question certain judgments of the Court of Justice of the European Communities have determined that the relevant provisions of the EEC Treaty are directly applicable. The resulting situation may affect a number of enactments and accordingly the Attorney General is considering what may be necessary by way of revision of the Moneylenders Act, 1933 and certain other enactments.
In response to my request for the views of interested organisations, one community association submitted a memorandum, which is being examined.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Hip Operations.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lemass Mr. Lemass
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if his attention has been drawn to a report to the effect that 50,000 Irish people need hip operations and the statement that many more may require it; whether this is the true position; and if there will be sufficient beds in this country to accommodate these patients.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: I have seen the report referred to, which is the opinion of an individual orthopaedic surgeon. My Department are not aware of any statistical evidence to support this estimate of 50,000 people needing hip replacement operations. Recent enquiries made by my Department indicate that the total waiting list for all classes of joint replacement operations, including hip replacement is approximately 1,000.

Much of this waiting list is due, I am advised, to the dramatic recent improvement in technique of joint replacement which offers the capability of relief for many cases which would not have benefited from earlier techniques. Once this backlog of these has been dealt with, the annual recurring demand should settle at a lower figure.
I am, however, keeping this position under review and will consider if further steps may be needed to cope with the situation. It does not appear that the major need at present is for extra beds.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lemass Mr. Lemass
Speaker.P: Even if the original estimate was very much exaggerated, would the Minister not consider a waiting list of 1,000 to be excessive?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Corish Mr. Corish
Speaker.P: It appears excessive but I am informed that there are 1,400 beds for such cases. As I have said there is a rush for this sort of operation. I expect that many Deputies have been approached by their constituents with a view to getting beds for them in the various hospitals so that they could undergo this operation. The reason why so many people have applied for the operation is that a new technique is being employed. It is proposed to advertise for the type of consultant involved in the hope that the employing of more consultants will result in the backlog being reduced. I expect that when the backlog has been cleared, demand will even off.

Speaker.P: Would the Minister accept that because of the publicity given to the free hospitalisation scheme, many people may not have continued with adequate VHI cover?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Corish Mr. Corish
Speaker.P: I am informed otherwise. I am told that there are 510,000 subscribers and that of these, 200,000 are in the limited eligibility category, that is, in the middle income group. There was no fall whatever in the number for March-April, 1974. As I indicated in my reply, subscribers are notified at intervals of the maintenance and treatment units necessary to ensure adequate cover.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Corish Mr. Corish
Speaker.P: No. I am merely giving the Deputy the figures I have. I have no comparative figures as between now and 12 months ago.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Corish Mr. Corish
Speaker.P: I have no comment to make on it or on any speculation in any newspaper or periodical in respect of anything.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: But the Minister is not saying that decisions have not been made?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Corish Mr. Corish
Speaker.P: Decisions have not been made.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Davern Mr. Davern
Speaker.P: None at all?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: No answer.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy

You, Sir, ruled the question out of order, I was informed by your letter of yesterday, because you said the Minister had no official responsibility in relation to this matter. Could you distinguish between the reasons why you allowed these two questions but disallowed my question?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Lynch Mr. J. Lynch
Speaker.P: I am just referring to the fact that there are two questions pertaining to other State sponsored bodies allowed which the Minister is, apparently, expected to answer and for which he has apparently accepted responsibility. Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Lynch Mr. J. Lynch

MainHeading.Title: Private Notice Question: - Mayo Factory Dispute.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour the immediate action he proposes to take in the dispute at the Leisure Wear factory, Ballina, County Mayo, which is due to close this week if there is no settlement, with a consequent loss of over 50 jobs.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Local Government (Mr. Tully) (for the Minister for Labour) James Tully
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Local Government (Mr. Tully) (for the Minister for Labour)
Speaker.P: Discussions in relation to the matters at issue in this dispute are continuing. The Conciliation Service of the Labour Court is in touch with the parties to the dispute.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: Can the Minister tell me what steps he can take to ensure the guarantees given to the IDA and the unions will be acted upon by the company and what steps can he take to ensure that any money due to the employees will be paid?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Tully Mr. Tully
Speaker.P: The question of wages is a matter of a simple contract debt and can be dealt with in the normal way, but it has not reached that stage. I understand discussions took place last evening between the IDA, representatives of the parent company in Leicester and representatives of the Irish Transport and General Workers Union. There was a great deal of misunderstanding and the matter now appears to be clarified. The company have indicated they now propose to continue operations.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: Will the Minister accept that most of the stock, finished and unfinished, including samples and waste, has been taken from the factory and six machines have also been taken from the factory? Is the Minister satisfied that sufficient is being done by the State agencies to monitor the progress of this company and will he consult with his colleague, the Minister for Industry and Commerce, as to what steps he may take to provide alternative employment for those now out of work, some of whom will not qualify for any State benefit or assistance?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Tully Mr. Tully
Speaker.P: I do not think the matter should be pursued along these lines. I have stated that, following discussions yesterday evening, a number of misunderstandings which had occurred and would, apparently, result in the closure of the factory have been ironed out and it is now proposed to restart work and continue in operation. What Deputy Calleary has said with regard to the removal of finished and unfinished material and some machinery is correct but, despite that position, the matter now appears to have been clarified and I am hopeful work will resume.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: I accept what the Minister has said but will the Minister accept from me that at 12.30 today some of the staff in the factory did not know this? I was in communication with people employed in the factory and they did not know this and were not happy about the position.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Tully Mr. Tully
Speaker.P: I have been in discussion with Senator Paddy O'Toole, who was in communication with Ballina at about 3 o'clock, and he had a little bit later information than Deputy Calleary has, but there were grounds for disquiet.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Lynch Mr. J. Lynch
Speaker.P: Deputy Calleary is a representative of the people.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Tully Mr. Tully
Speaker.P: Is Deputy Lynch suggesting a Senator is not a representative of the people?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Lynch Mr. J. Lynch
Speaker.P: It is a different type of representation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Tully Mr. Tully
Speaker.P: It is a different type now from the time when the Deputy was in charge. When the Deputy was Taoiseach it was a different type and it is different now.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Order.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Tully Mr. Tully
Speaker.P: If Deputy Calleary and the Fianna Fáil Party want to cause damage in this factory let them go on doing what they are doing now. I am saying the matter has now been clarified and it is hoped to resume work next week. I hope that will be accepted.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Order.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: Deputy Calleary has no intention at all of causing any trouble. Perhaps the Minister might explain the situation to those who are worried.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Tully Mr. Tully
Speaker.P: It has been explained.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: I want to ask one supplementary.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: It seems to me there have been a great many supplementary questions.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: I want to ask the Minister if he is aware that in this particular case there were implications that could be very serious for factories like this and if he is further aware of the reasons why this equipment and stock were removed from this factory? Would he advise his colleague now to take steps to ensure there will never be a repetition of this by any company operating here?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Tully Mr. Tully
Speaker.P: I shall be glad to tell the Minister for Labour what the Deputy has said but the Deputy will remember that this is something which has happened under existing legislation and the Deputy should be well aware of where that legislation started. As far as we are concerned the Conciliation Service has done a good job and the Department of Labour are doing a good job. For goodness sake, do not let us now start fishing in muddy waters and causing more damage than has already been caused.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Item No. 10. Capital Gains Tax Bill, 1974 (resumed).

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: The Department of Labour were not involved in the discussion last night.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: May I ask the Minister, in view of the allegations and the accusations made——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: No, I have called the next business. The Deputy must obey the Chair at some stage.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: I promise to be very brief.

Speaker.P: No, Deputy, I have called the next business.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Fitzgerald Mr. G. Fitzgerald

Speaker.P: I have given the Deputy every latitude.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Tully Mr. Tully
